elements.content: Integration of macrocyclic ligands into a polymeric matrix leads to a relatively new class of compounds with a wide range of applications (e.g., efficient and economical industrial separations, ion transportation, isotope extraction, anion activation, sensoring and switching, liquid crystalline properties, catalysis, etc.). Recently, we and others have shown that macrocyclic ligands can be imbedded into rigid layered frameworks of zirconium phosphates through exocyclic phosphorylation of crown ethers. Our efforts to further investigate the supramolecular assemblies based on exocyclic functional groups of crown ethers resulted in unprecedented “leaflet” (or “branch”) structures as shown in Figure a. In this communication, we report the synthesis and structural features of two supramolecular macrocyclic leaflets, which are stabilized by hydrogen bonding and coordination bonding networks.
elements.clean_text: Integration of macrocyclic ligands into a polymeric matrix leads to a relatively new class of compounds with a wide range of applications (e.g., efficient and economical industrial separations, ion transportation, isotope extraction, anion activation, sensoring and switching, liquid crystalline properties, catalysis, etc.). Recently, we and others have shown that macrocyclic ligands can be imbedded into rigid layered frameworks of zirconium phosphates through exocyclic phosphorylation of crown ethers. Our efforts to further investigate the supramolecular assemblies based on exocyclic functional groups of crown ethers resulted in unprecedented "leaflet" (or "branch") structures as shown in Figure a. In this communication, we report the synthesis and structural features of two supramolecular macrocyclic leaflets, which are stabilized by hydrogen bonding and coordination bonding networks.

elements.content: (a) A schematic representation of “macrocyclic leaflets” formed by self-assembly ofN-(phosphonomethyl)-aza-18-crown-6 ethers. PLUTO diagram of the leaflet's backbone formed through hydrogen bonds (b) and coordination bonds (c). The crown ether moieties are omitted and O atoms in the coordination network are not earmarked for the sake of clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) A schematic representation of "macrocyclic leaflets" formed by self-assembly ofN-(phosphonomethyl)-aza-18-crown-6 ethers. PLUTO diagram of the leaflet's backbone formed through hydrogen bonds (b) and coordination bonds (c). The crown ether moieties are omitted and O atoms in the coordination network are not earmarked for the sake of clarity.

elements.content: It has been known that metal(IV) phosphates/phosphonates (e.g., Zr(O3P-R/O3P-OR)2) form predictable layered structures when the size of the R groups is less than the free area around the metal atoms, 0.24 nm2, in the layer. However, the poor solubility and low crystallinity of these materials make their structural characterization a difficult task. On the other hand, metal(II) phosphonates are relatively more soluble and often form single crystals. For these reasons, we have decided to study the metal(II) complexes of phosphonated crown ethers to understand the selectivity, conformational rigidity, and other important structural properties of polymeric crown ether assemblies in the solid state.
elements.clean_text: It has been known that metal(IV) phosphates/phosphonates (e.g., Zr(O3P-R/O3P-OR)2) form predictable layered structures when the size of the R groups is less than the free area around the metal atoms, 0.24 nm2, in the layer. However, the poor solubility and low crystallinity of these materials make their structural characterization a difficult task. On the other hand, metal(II) phosphonates are relatively more soluble and often form single crystals. For these reasons, we have decided to study the metal(II) complexes of phosphonated crown ethers to understand the selectivity, conformational rigidity, and other important structural properties of polymeric crown ether assemblies in the solid state.

elements.content: Monoaza-18-crown-6 was phosphonomethylated by reacting it with phosphorous acid and formaldehyde in the presence of concentrated HCl. Isolation and purification of N-(phosphonomethyl)-aza-18-crown-6, 1H 2 N, was achieved by treating the reaction mixture with an ion exchange column followed by recrystallization in ethanol (Scheme ). An ethanolic solution (10 mL) of crown ether 1H 2 N (0.036 g, 0.1 mmol) was layered with metal salts Co(ClO4)2·6H2O (0.037 g, 0.1 mmol, 15 mL) and Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (0.031 g, 0.1 mmol, 15 mL) dissolved in EtOH to obtain single crystals of the complexes, 2 [(1H 1.5 NH·H2O)2·(ClO4)] and 3 [Cd4(1NH·H2O)3·(H2O)5(NO3)4][NO3]. These crystals were subjected to X-ray crystallographic studies using a Bruker-AXS CCD diffractometer.
elements.clean_text: Monoaza-18-crown-6 was phosphonomethylated by reacting it with phosphorous acid and formaldehyde in the presence of concentrated HCl. Isolation and purification of N-(phosphonomethyl)-aza-18-crown-6, 1H  2  N, was achieved by treating the reaction mixture with an ion exchange column followed by recrystallization in ethanol (Scheme ). An ethanolic solution (10 mL) of crown ether 1H  2  N (0.036 g, 0.1 mmol) was layered with metal salts Co(ClO4)2⋅6H2O (0.037 g, 0.1 mmol, 15 mL) and Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (0.031 g, 0.1 mmol, 15 mL) dissolved in EtOH to obtain single crystals of the complexes, 2 [(1H  1.5  NH⋅H2O)2⋅(ClO4)] and 3 [Cd4(1NH⋅H2O)3⋅(H2O)5(NO3)4][NO3]. These crystals were subjected to X-ray crystallographic studies using a Bruker-AXS CCD diffractometer.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="ja9938377h00001" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="ja9938377h00001.gif"></graphic>
</fig>

Interestingly, Co(II) does not form a complex with acid 1H 2 N, rather the ClO4 anions enter into the crystal lattice of complex 2 for balancing the charge as the phosphonic acid anion is only half deprotonated and the amine is fully protonated (1H 1.5 NH). In other words, the azacrown ether moiety bears a net charge of +0.5 and two positively charged azacrown ethers together balance the charge of every ClO4 - anion. The phosphonic acids self-assemble through hydrogen-bonded dimers and symmetrical hydrogen bonds using 1.5 acidic protons to form a unique polyphosphonate chain flanked by crown ethers such as a leaflet (O···O, 2.415(2) Å, 2.501(3) Å, Figures b and a). Water molecules occupy the molecular cavities of the crown ethers and hydrogen bond with ethereal O atoms and the N−H proton (five O···O contacts in the range of 2.9−3.0 Å, N···O 2.686(3) Å).
elements.clean_text: Interestingly, Co(II) does not form a complex with acid 1H  2  N, rather the ClO4 anions enter into the crystal lattice of complex 2 for balancing the charge as the phosphonic acid anion is only half deprotonated and the amine is fully protonated (1H  1.5  NH). In other words, the azacrown ether moiety bears a net charge of +0.5 and two positively charged azacrown ethers together balance the charge of every ClO4 - anion. The phosphonic acids self-assemble through hydrogen-bonded dimers and symmetrical hydrogen bonds using 1.5 acidic protons to form a unique polyphosphonate chain flanked by crown ethers such as a leaflet (O⋅⋅⋅O, 2.415(2) Å, 2.501(3) Å, Figures b and a). Water molecules occupy the molecular cavities of the crown ethers and  hydrogen bond with ethereal O atoms and the N-H proton (five O⋅⋅⋅O contacts in the range of 2.9-3.0 Å, N⋅⋅⋅O 2.686(3) Å).

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of complex 3 contains four Cd(II) cations, three phosphonate anions, 1NH, five nitrate anions, and eight water molecules. Interestingly, 3 also forms a leaflet structure like 2, but has a complicated polymeric coordination network as the backbone, in which Cd(II) cations adopt octahedral geometry and form two unique Cd···Cd metal contacts (3.288(3) and 3.470(2) Å, Figures c and b). The phosphonate anions not only bridge the metal cations that make short contacts but also interconnect them further to form a 1D polymeric network (Cd−O distances range from 2.21 to 2.40 Å). Each metal cation is coordinated with at least one nitrate anion and a water molecule and two of the four metal coordinated nitrate anions additionally bridge the adjacent metal cations. In effect, the polymeric chain is positively charged and the free nitrate anions balance the charge. The crown ethers of the leaflet structure encapsulate water molecules such as 1 and form multiple hydrogen bonds. There are five O···O contacts in the range of 2.75−3.0 Å in each of the three crystallographically distinct crown ethers along with N−H···O hydrogen bonds (N···O 2.734(15), 2.708(16), and 2.722(16) Å).
elements.clean_text: The asymmetric unit of complex 3 contains four Cd(II) cations, three phosphonate anions, 1NH, five nitrate anions, and eight water molecules. Interestingly, 3 also forms a leaflet structure like 2, but has a complicated polymeric coordination network as the backbone, in which Cd(II) cations adopt octahedral geometry and form two unique Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd metal contacts (3.288(3) and 3.470(2) Å, Figures c and b). The phosphonate anions not only bridge the metal cations that make short contacts but also interconnect them further to form a 1D polymeric network (Cd-O distances range from 2.21 to 2.40 Å). Each metal cation is coordinated with at least one nitrate anion and a water molecule and two of the four metal coordinated nitrate anions additionally bridge the adjacent metal cations. In effect, the polymeric chain is positively charged and the free nitrate anions balance the charge. The crown ethers of the leaflet structure encapsulate water molecules such as 1 and form multiple hydrogen bonds. There are five O⋅⋅⋅O contacts in the range of 2.75-3.0 Å in each of the three crystallographically distinct crown ethers along with N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds (N⋅⋅⋅O 2.734(15), 2.708(16), and 2.722(16) Å).

elements.content: The macrocyclic leaflets of2 (a) and 3 (b). Water molecules encapsulated in the crown ethers are highlighted (H atoms are not shown for 3). Note the subtle differences in the alignment of crown ethers in 2 and 3.
elements.clean_text: 2  The macrocyclic leaflets of2 (a) and 3 (b). Water molecules encapsulated in the crown ethers are highlighted (H atoms are not shown for 3). Note the subtle differences in the alignment of crown ethers in 2 and 3.

elements.content: The crown ethers in the polymeric matrix of complex 2 are coplanar and stack at an interplanar distance of ca. 3.8 Å, while in 3 the crown ethers are inclined at angles 4.7° and 5.4° and stack with interplanar distances of ca. 3.5 and 3.6 Å. The packing diagram of 2 and 3 reveals the continuous open channels formed through stacking of crown ether moieties (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: The crown ethers in the polymeric matrix of complex 2 are coplanar and stack at an interplanar distance of ca. 3.8 Å, while in 3 the crown ethers are inclined at angles 4.7° and 5.4° and stack with interplanar distances of ca. 3.5 and 3.6 Å. The packing diagram of 2 and 3 reveals the continuous open channels formed through stacking of crown ether moieties (Figure ).

elements.content: Packing diagram of the “macrocyclic leaflets”. Note the formation of continuous channels in2 (a) and 3 (b). Such an arrangement of crown ethers may facilitate ion transportation. Perchlorate anions in 2 are disordered.
elements.clean_text: 3  Packing diagram of the "macrocyclic leaflets". Note the formation of continuous channels in2 (a) and 3 (b). Such an arrangement of crown ethers may facilitate ion transportation. Perchlorate anions in 2 are disordered.

elements.content: The structural features of complexes 2 and 3 are of great interest for their exquisite aesthetic appeal and for the following reasons:  (i) Crystal structures of 2 and 3 suggest novel supramolecular routes for grafting crown ethers into a polymeric matrix. (ii) Deprotonation of organophosphonic acids leads to the formation of hydrogen-bonded polyphosphonate chains. (iii) The polymeric assemblies of crown ethers formed through self-assembly of exocyclic functional groups may exhibit distinct selectivity as compared to simple crown ethers in the solution or the solid state because the polymeric assemblies can either encapsulate or sandwich the metal cations in their molecular cavities. Further, the cooperative effects of metal cation insertion and relative orientation of crown ethers with respect to each other may influence the metal binding properties. These factors may be of significant importance in the separation of metal ion isotopes. (iv) The stacking arrangement of macrocycles in 2 and 3 provides new models for the design of macrocyclic tubular channels for transporting ionic species and discotic liquid crystals.
elements.clean_text: The structural features of complexes 2 and 3 are of great interest for their exquisite aesthetic appeal and for the following reasons: (i) Crystal structures of 2 and 3 suggest novel supramolecular routes for grafting crown ethers into a polymeric matrix. (ii) Deprotonation of organophosphonic acids leads to the formation of hydrogen-bonded polyphosphonate chains. (iii) The polymeric assemblies of crown ethers formed through self-assembly of exocyclic functional groups may exhibit distinct selectivity as compared to simple crown ethers in the solution or the solid state because the polymeric assemblies can either encapsulate or sandwich the metal cations in their molecular cavities. Further, the cooperative effects of metal cation insertion and relative orientation of crown ethers with respect to each other may influence the metal binding properties. These factors may be of significant importance in the separation of metal ion isotopes. (iv) The stacking arrangement of macrocycles in 2 and 3 provides new models for the design of macrocyclic tubular channels for transporting ionic species and discotic liquid crystals.
